Topic.Title: SHORTS COVER NOW! DON'T FIGHT FED!

Message.Msg: I'm sitting tight. POMO has provided a nice lift most of the time (because the entire market is levitating on option scalping, which works until it doesn't) -- providing enough inflow to offset the necessary outflow required by those with fewer financial assets forced to consume wealth to deal with the real world inflation in necessities. I suspect they'll try to take it up again. But, smart investors with more than a month horizon will be selling straight through any such attempt and playing the AAPLtrage game (or simply raising cash). As I've said a million times, AMZN is just hosed this year. I've yet to see an analyst that properly breaks down the profit driver on the physical goods business. If they did, they'd understand what I said to NAS... increasing gas prices hurt but declining gas prices will not help (has to do with the cause of the rise/decline in gas).

Topic.Title: Can someone explain why a stock with a forward PE of 70+ & little cash/share is better than a a stock with 10 PE & lots of cash?

Message.Msg: Kenji: One of many malls. With inferior economics that will, within the next 12 months, be unequivocally exposed as such. The reality is that Amazon is probably the most overhyped company in history. The underlying economic tradeoff was much better for Amazon in 2002 than today. eBay is focused on sharpening the offering vis-a vis 3P. Google's Shopping platform better aligns to retailer incentive and will be inherently more efficient for most product categories. With broader systems integration on inventory and local/courier delivery optimization, it can outcompete Amazon on price and convenience (plus local retailers retain sales, which is better for local economies and a vulnerability for Amazon moving forward).. Amazon will have sunk enormous capital into building out redundant, non distincitve infrastructure. It has been systematically rewarded for epic malinvestment and now the bill will come due. For those of you keeping score, follow Amazon's GROSS SHIPPING as a % of net sales. Some analysts pointed out that net shipping as a percent of sales declined from 2011 to 2012. What they didn't mention was the increased internal revenue transfers (Prime in 2012 and shipping revenue) that enabled it. Comparing to 2010 rather than 2011, net shipping has grown as a % of sales, even with the Prime and shipping revenue offsets, despite the massive buildout. If the buildout story was true, it should have reduced both gross and net shipping as a percent of net sales... Amazon just hiked rates because the YOY comps would have made the real economics clear if it didn't. But, as predicted, it has now #$%$ off 3P partners because the underlying economics have moved and will continue to move against it. It will have to do the same to customers soon enough...

Topic.Title: Can someone explain why a stock with a forward PE of 70+ & little cash/share is better than a a stock with 10 PE & lots of cash?

Message.Msg: While you're at it: please explain why a company buys back over a billion dollars worth of it's own stock over the last 18 months at a premium price, then borrow $2 billion to pay for capital expenditures? The reason for the buyback is obvious: to buyback the vesting stock options stock that would otherwise dilute the eps and drive down the stock price. Amzn would have to spend another billion + this year to do the same thing. Microsoft used to be the master of this - buying back all the stock they granted employees - of course, MS could do that out of cash flow and still have cash left over. If Amzn stops propping up it's own stock - how much will that effect share price? If they keep buying shares, how much more money will the company borrow to satisfy Bezo's need to keep spending? Bad business practices can't go on forever...this stock is beginning to smell like burnt toast..
